summary: This is an email chain from August 2019 between officials at the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, discussing the sharing of Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) information related to Jeffrey Epstein. It shows coordination between financial crime investigators and federal prosecutors on the Epstein case shortly after his arrest.

persons.name: Assistant Chief Counsel
persons.context: The sender of the main email from FinCEN, copying an Intelligence Division contact to facilitate information sharing about Epstein with the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Co-Chief, Money Laundering and Transnational Criminal Enterprises Unit
persons.context: A prosecutor from the Southern District of New York who is cc'd on the email chain to coordinate receipt of FinCEN's SAR information on Epstein.

connections.person2: Co-Chief, Money Laundering and Transnational Criminal Enterprises Unit
connections.description: FinCEN counsel is connecting with a federal prosecutor to share financial intelligence (SARs) related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: FinCEN-US Attorney Coordination on Epstein SARs
events.description: Email correspondence where FinCEN offers to share Suspicious Activity Report information on Jeffrey Epstein with prosecutors from the Southern District of New York.
personsInvolved: Co-Chief, Money Laundering and Transnational Criminal Enterprises Unit

keyFacts: The Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) possessed Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) related to Jeffrey Epstein and was proactively offering this information to federal prosecutors in August 2019.
The communication shows active inter-agency coordination between financial crime investigators (FinCEN) and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York on the Epstein case.
The email chain is dated shortly after Epstein's arrest in July 2019, indicating a rapid mobilization to gather financial intelligence as part of the investigation.
